comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content: Who was manning the road block, I wonder? British or Irish soldiers? They are wearing Pattern 1914 leather webbing, that integrated the Pattern 1908 canvas webbing during the Great War. They are also carrying extra cloth cartridge bandoliers for fast reloading. Leather Pattern 1914 webbing was withdrawn by the Britsih Military in 1921, but no doubt it remained in service longer in other militaries that used Britsh equipment. Here's an interesting website about webbing www.karkeeweb.com/1914main.html

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content:
In this 1919 photo, taken in Germany, my great grandfather (to the right) is wearing a Pattern 1908 canvas webbing belt, while his friend to the left has a pattern 1914 leather one.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/patrick_castelli/5922054314/]

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content: I just saw the date the photo was taken on, so these must be British soldiers, and as all canvas Pattern 1908 webbing was reserved for front line troops, that explains the use of leather Pattern 1914!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/patrick_castelli] Sorry, Patrick, didn't get to this quickly enough, but sure you answered your own question without me! :)

However, it's an interesting point, and made me return to the description above. I had put in "British soldiers", but have now amended it to "British ARMY soldiers". Those individual men could have been Irish, English, Welsh or Scottish...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] True, I was wondering that myself, they might even have belonged to locally recruited Irish regiments.
Even if I suspect that the British War Office made sure all Irish soldiers were stationed and trained away from Ireland...for obvious reasons!

comment.author: 24101413@N03
comment._content: The car is a Morris Oxford, produced in 1913-14 and the first Morris car.  It was nicknamed the "Bullnose" on account of the bullet-shaped radiator.

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: At last - a photo I know something about! The schoolhouse in the background was briefly occupied by the rebels and part of the wooden ceiling indoors still has bullet damage visible - an interesting distraction while having a beer! Almost directly in front of the car was Clanwilliam House - occupied by the rebels and from where they put up a very strong fight. Finally set on fire by bullets and grenades, the house burned to the ground, along with some of the dead rebels inside. Only a leg and some bone fragments were recovered. When the house was burning uncontrollably and the shooting had stopped, the flames spread to the house next door - the residents, Mr & Mrs Mathis, could do nothing, so sat on deck chairs in the garden and watched their home burn.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65361386@N05] Amazing story, thank you! Had never heard about Mr and Mrs Mathis before. (And you know tons about photos!)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: I hope his tax and insurance were OK.

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: Slight correction (thanks to the online 1911 census!) - they were Janet and Andrew Mathers.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65361386@N05] Ah, you're excellent to come back to us on that! Thank you.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 26640250@N02
comment._content:
This is indeed the site of the battle of Mount Street bridge, where Irish rebels held off the arrival of the British Army from Dun Laoire (Kingstown) to quell the rising. There were large losses among the British at this site.
The length of and direction of the shadows suggest the image was captured in the afternoon with the sun reaonably high in the sky.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sebfotos] Good point about the shadows! Love to establish times of the photos, whether through clocks/watches, or this more boy scout approach!  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: According to the Irish Motor Directory and Motorists' Annual for 1915-16, the owner of RI 2987 was Frank D. Mockler, Dunavara, Lucan.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Census form from 1911 for Mr Frank D Mockler He would have been 48 in 1916. He stated "none" under rank, profession or occupation for both himself and his American wife of 9 years Kate Bommell. He had 4 servants including a Groom in 1911. so presume this is before he owned a car? He was not in Ireland for the 1901 census, perhaps off in America finding a wife and a fortune so allowing him to be a man of leisure in 1911????

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Or I wonder if Groom could equal Chauffeur in those days? This is all fantastic and a very ecumenical household with a good mix of religions.

P.S. Your profile pic made me laugh, but I want to see how much of our logo your ickle birdie will eat!  :D

comment._content:
any chance of finding out who the registered owner of the second vehicle was?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/83987525@N04] There is indeed, Johnny. See part of my description above under the photo:
... The car registration is RI 2987. (Dublin registered - RI 1 to 9999 ran from December 1903 to April 1921). According to the Irish Motor Directory and Motorists' Annual for 1915-16, the owner of RI 2987 was Frank D. Mockler, Dunavara, Lucan...
We have a copy of that Directory for 1915-16 at Library Towers. I'll try to check for reg. no. LH 5784 this week for you (so long as it was an Irish registered car). Nag me here if you don't see any information appearing by Wednesday or so... Plus, don't think we know the photographer, but it appeared in the Irish Independent. May just have been one of their staff photographers.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 83987525@N04
comment._content: thanks. Are the Motor Directories available for Joe Public (ie me ;-) ) to view at the NLI? I'm doing some work on the early Guinness lorries and would like to see if I can tally some registrations numbers I do have and perhaps find out about those I don't have.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/83987525@N04] Absolutely! You just need to come in, bring some id, and get yourself a reader's ticket. I can't remember the ref. no. for this Directory, but I'll try to check it tomorrow. Then I'll let you know so you can order it before you come in. The only issue is that as far as I recall, we only have a few of the very early years of the 20th century. You might have a look too at the Guinness Archives. I met the archivist last week before she gave a great talk about the fantastic records they have there - so you could try filling in their enquiry form on this page of their website...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: If taken in 1920 this photograph was taken after the Bloody Sunday killings on the 21st November when Collins went after the Cairo gang. Seán Lemass was involved in the killing of a Captain Bagely on Mount Street, while in two further incidents on the same street three more British agents were killed. Only a few streets away, further shootings took place on Baggot Street, Fitzwilliam Square, Morehampton Road and Earlsfort Terrace. This has to be an aftermath checkpoint.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: But if 1916 was taken after the Battle of Mount Street! The car is facing Clanwilliam House. Great description of the Battle of Mount Street Bridge here. (British POV) [http://www.flickr.com/photos/35117052@N07/6806932344/in/photolist-bnviQu] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/westernfrontassociation/6806932894/] 25 Northumberland Road. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/westernfrontassociation/6806933824/] www.nli.ie/1916/pdf/7.11.pdf
